revision.comment: http→https for [[Google Books]] and [[Google News]] using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{good article}} {{Infobox Hurricane | Name=Hurricane Janet | Type=hurricane | Year=1955 | Basin=Atl | Image location=Hurricane Janet analysis 28 Sep 1955.png | Image name=[[Surface weather analysis]] of Hurricane Janet near peak intensity on September 28, 1955 | Image alt=A contoured map showing intervals of pressure changes with contour lines. The contoured lines are concentrated near the bottom of the picture, indicating an area of low pressure. | Formed=September 21, 1955 | Dissipated=September 30, 1955 | 1-min winds=150 | Pressurepre=≤ | Pressure=914 | Damages=65.8 | Inflated=1 | Fatalities=1,023+ direct | Areas=[[Barbados]], [[Windward Islands]], [[British Honduras]], [[Yucatán Peninsula]], Mainland [[Mexico]] | Hurricane season=[[1955 Atlantic hurricane season]] }} '''Hurricane Janet''' was the most powerful [[tropical cyclone]] of the [[1955 Atlantic hurricane season]] and one of the strongest [[North Atlantic tropical cyclone|Atlantic hurricane]]s on record. The eleventh tropical storm, ninth hurricane, and fifth [[Category 3 hurricane|major hurricane]] of the year,{{#tag:ref|A major hurricane is a storm that ranks as Category 3 or higher on the [[Saffir–Simpson hurricane scale]].{{cite book|author=Goldenburg, Stan|chapter=A3) What is a super-typhoon? What is a major hurricane? What is an intense hurricane?|type=FAQ|title=Frequently Asked Questions|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/weather_sub/faq.html|chapterurl=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/tcfaq/A3.html|date=June 1, 2012|publisher=United States National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's Atlantic Oceanographic and Meteorological Laboratory|accessdate=February 18, 2013|version=4.5}}|group="nb"}} Janet formed from a [[tropical wave]] east of the [[Lesser Antilles]] on September 21. Moving westward across the [[Caribbean Sea]], Janet fluctuated in intensity, but generally strengthened before reaching its peak intensity as a [[List of Category 5 Atlantic hurricanes|Category 5 hurricane]] with winds of 175 mph (280 km/h). The intense hurricane later made [[landfall (meteorology)|landfall]] at that intensity near [[Chetumal, Mexico]] on September 28. After weakening over the [[Yucatán Peninsula]], it moved into the [[Bay of Campeche]], where it slightly strengthened before making its final landfall near [[Veracruz, Veracruz|Veracruz]] on September 29. Janet quickly weakened over Mexico's mountainous terrain before dissipating on September 30. In its developmental stages, Janet caused $7.8 million in damage to the Lesser Antilles and 189 deaths in the [[Grenadines]] and [[Barbados]].{{#tag:ref|All damage totals are in 1955 [[United States dollar]]s unless otherwise noted.|group="nb"}} While Janet was in the central Caribbean Sea, a [[Hurricane Hunters|reconnaissance aircraft]] flew into the storm and was lost, with all eleven crew members believed to be perished. This remains the only such loss which has occurred in association with an Atlantic hurricane. A Category 5 upon landfall on the Yucatán Peninsula, Janet caused severe devastation in areas of [[Quintana Roo]] and [[British Honduras]]. Only five buildings in [[Chetumal, Mexico]] remained intact after the storm, and an estimated 500 deaths occurred in the [[Administrative divisions of Mexico|Mexican state]] of Quintana Roo. At Janet's second landfall near Veracruz, significant river [[flooding]] ensued, worsening effects caused by Hurricanes [[Hurricane Gladys (1955)|Gladys]] and [[Hurricane Hilda (1955)|Hilda]] earlier in the month. The floods left thousands of people stranded and killed at least 326 people in the Tampico area, leading to the largest Mexican relief operation ever executed by the United States. Janet's landfall as a Category 5 hurricane on the Yucatán Peninsula was the first recorded instance that a storm of such intensity in the Atlantic made landfall on a continental [[mainland]]; prior to Janet, landfalls of Category 5 intensity were only known to have taken place on islands.{{cite web|title=Category 5 MONSTERS!|url=http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/oa/satellite/satelliteseye/educational/cat5hur.html|publisher=United States National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|accessdate=February 2, 2013|author=National Climatic Data Center}} Janet's minimum [[barometric pressure]], recorded in Chetumal, was at the time the second lowest recorded pressure on land associated with a tropical cyclone in the Atlantic, behind the [[1935 Labor Day Hurricane]]. At least 1,023 deaths were attributed to Hurricane Janet, as well as $65.8 million in damages. The name Janet was later [[List of retired Atlantic hurricane names|retired]] from the Atlantic list of tropical cyclone names due to its significance to the scientific research community. ==Meteorological history== [[File:Janet 1955 track.png|left|thumb|Storm path|alt=A map showing the path of a hurricane, with colored dots representing the storm's position at six-hour intervals, as well as its intensity based on a color scheme. The path begins at the right, moves generally to the left and crosses two land masses during that trek.]] A weak tropical disturbance was first reported by the [[Air France]] and [[Iberia (airline)|Iberia]] airlines east of the [[Lesser Antilles]] early on September 21. Although it was speculated that the disturbance originated from a [[tropical wave]] near [[Cape Verde]], the [[National Hurricane Center|Weather Bureau]] considered the system too weak to be detected due to a lack of [[weather forecasting|reports]] from the islands.{{cite journal|author=Dunn, Gordon E.|author2=Davis, Walter R. |author3=Moore, Paul L. |title=Hurricanes of 1955|journal=Monthly Weather Review|date=December 1, 1955|volume=83|issue=12|pages=315–326|format=PDF|doi=10.1175/1520-0493(1955)083<0315:HO>2.0.CO;2|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1955.pdf|accessdate=January 21, 2013|publisher=American Meteorological Society|location=Weather Bureau Office, Miami, Florida |bibcode=1955MWRv...83..315D }} See pp. 321-323. At 1800 [[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]] on September 21, while it was located 350 mi (565 km) east-southeast of [[Martinique]],{{Atlantic hurricane best track}}{{cite news|title=Hurricane Janet Tenth of Season|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=kUEpAAAAIBAJ&sjid=j2YFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2750,2029661&dq=janet&hl=en|accessdate=January 21, 2013|newspaper=The Lewiston Daily Sun|date=September 22, 1955|agency=Associated Press|location=Miami, Florida|page=10}} the disturbance became sufficiently organized for the Weather Bureau to classify it as Tropical Storm Janet, the tenth named storm of the season. Upon classification, Janet quickly intensified as it moved to the west.{{Atlantic hurricane best track}}{{cite report|publisher=United States Department of Commerce|author=United States Weather Bureau|title=Bulletins and Advisories Issued by Weather Bureau Airport Station, San Juan, Puerto Rico, Weather Bureau Office, Miami, Florida, and Weather Bureau Office, New Orleans, Louisiana on Hurricane "Janet"|type=Preliminary Report|pages=1–14|accessdate=January 21, 2013|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/hurricanes/Qc9452j26b81955.pdf|format=PDF}} On September 22, Janet attained hurricane strength, and proceeded to [[rapid deepening|rapidly intensify]] as it moved westward across the [[Windward Islands]]. By 1200 UTC that day, Janet already attained [[Category 3 hurricane|Category 3 hurricane]] strength with [[maximum sustained wind]]s of 120 mph (195 km/h), before stalling in intensification.{{Atlantic hurricane best track}} Shortly after 1700 UTC on September 22, the [[eye (cyclone)|eye]] of Janet passed over [[Barbados]].{{cite news |title=Remembrance service for Janet's victims |author=Staff writer |url=http://www.barbadosadvocate.com/newsitem.asp?more=local&NewsID=12859|newspaper=The Barbados Advocate |date=September 20, 2010 |accessdate=February 2013 |trans_title= |quote=At the service, it was recalled that the natural disaster struck the island on September 22, 1955. The death toll was recorded at 33, with an additional two persons missing at sea. 150 people were injured needing hospital treatment. Over 8 000 homes were destroyed and 20 000 people made homeless. |archiveurl= |archivedate= |deadurl= |ref=}} A [[Hurricane Hunters|reconnaissance flight]] into the hurricane discovered that the Hurricane Janet's eye measured only 20 mi (32 km) in diameter, with gale force winds extending 120 mi (190 km) away from the center of circulation. The flight also reported a minimum [[barometric pressure]] of 979 [[Bar (unit)|mbar]] ([[Pascal (unit)|hPa]]; 28.91 [[Inch of mercury|inHg]]). After passing between the islands of [[Grenada]] and [[Carriacou and Petite Martinique|Carriacou]] in the morning hours of September 23, Janet entered an area of unfavorable conditions in the eastern [[Caribbean Sea]]. As a result, the hurricane became disorganized, with winds weakening to 90 mph (145 km/h) by 1200 UTC on September 23.{{Atlantic hurricane best track}} A [[United States Navy|U.S. Navy]] reconnaissance plane entered the hurricane early on September 24, reporting a lack of organization, and noting an indiscernible center of circulation with weak [[rainbands]]. However, the hurricane began to reintensify in favorable conditions, regaining major hurricane strength by 1200 UTC on September 24 and subsequently [[Category 4 hurricane|Category 4 hurricane]] intensity by the next day.{{Atlantic hurricane best track}} [[File:Hurricane Janet Barograph Chetumal.png|thumb|Graph of barometer readings in Chetumal|alt=Chart showing a line which remains steady and suddenly drops near the center of the graph, representing a drop in barometric pressure, before rising again and steadying out.]] While trekking across the central Caribbean Sea, Janet was only slightly larger than while it was moving over the Windward Islands, with gale force winds extending 125 mi (200 km) out from the center by September 25. Remaining a Category 4 hurricane as it moved erratically westward across the Caribbean, a reconnaissance flight mission during the night of September 25–26 indicated strong rainbands with frequent [[lightning]] strikes and a well-defined eye, evidence that the storm was once again rapidly intensifying. As it neared the [[Yucatán Peninsula]] on September 26, Janet began accelerating in forward speed. After the reconnaissance flight ''Snowcloud Five'' was lost while making a penetration into the hurricane's eye, another flight early on September 27 reported a minimum pressure of 938 mbar (hPa; 27.70 inHg), with winds in excess of 115 mph (185 km/h) "by a large and incalculable amount." The hurricane was estimated to have intensified to [[Category 5 hurricane|Category 5 hurricane]] intensity—the highest rating on the modern day [[Saffir–Simpson hurricane scale]]—at 1200 UTC on September 27, while in the western Caribbean Sea. Janet continued to intensify afterwards, eventually reaching its peak intensity with maximum sustained winds of 175 mph (280 km/h),{{Atlantic hurricane best track}} with gale force winds having expanded to at least 250 mi (400 km) away from the center of the hurricane. Janet maintained peak intensity as it passed over the [[Swan Islands, Honduras|Swan Islands]] before making [[landfall (meteorology)|landfall]] in extreme southern Quintana Roo, Mexico, just east of [[Chetumal, Mexico]]. In that city, a [[barometer]] indicated a minimum barometric pressure of 914 mbar (hPa; 27.00 inHg) in the eye of Janet. At the time, this was the second lowest pressure ever recorded on land in a landfalling [[Atlantic hurricane]], behind the [[1935 Labor Day Hurricane]], though Janet was later surpassed by hurricanes [[Hurricane Dean|Dean]] and [[Hurricane Gilbert|Gilbert]], which also made landfall on the Yucatán Peninsula as Category 5 hurricanes.{{cite report|author=Franklin, James L.|date=January 31, 2008|title=Hurricane Dean|work=Tropical Cyclone Report|type=Preliminary Report|publisher=United States National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's National Hurricane Center|accessdate=January 21, 2013|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL042007_Dean}}|format=PDF}} Once over land, Janet considerably weakened to a [[Category 2 hurricane|Category 2 hurricane]] with winds of 105 mph (170 km/h). After crossing the Yucatán Peninsula with a forward speed of 21 mph (34 km/h), the hurricane emerged into the [[Bay of Campeche]] by 1600 UTC on September 28.{{Atlantic hurricane best track}} The weakened hurricane marginally intensified as it crossed the Bay of Campeche to a secondary peak intensity of 110 mph (175 km/h) with a minimum central pressure of 950 mbar (hPa; 28.06 inHg).{{Atlantic hurricane best track}} Janet eventually made its final landfall 50 mi (80 km) north of the city of [[Veracruz, Veracruz|Veracruz]] by 2200 UTC on September 29 as a Category 2 hurricane. After moving inland, the hurricane became quickly disorganized due to the highly mountainous terrain of [[Mexico]], and as a result the Weather Bureau issued its last advisory on Janet. The weakening system degenerated to tropical storm strength by September 30, and later dissipated over central Mexico by 0600 UTC that day.{{Atlantic hurricane best track}} Janet's remnant circulation contributed to the development of a disturbed area of weather off the western coast of Mexico that would subsequently develop into a [[1955 Pacific hurricane season#Tropical Storm Five|tropical storm]] on October 1. {{clear}} ==Preparations== ===Caribbean Islands=== Upon Janet's formation east of the Windward Islands, the Weather Bureau office in [[San Juan, Puerto Rico]] advised [[small craft advisory|small craft]] to remain in port and vessels in the path of the developing storm to exercise caution. After a reconnaissance flight reported much stronger winds than initially suggested, [[hurricane warning]]s were issued at 1600 UTC on September 22 for the entirety of the Lesser Antilles from [[Saint Lucia]] to Grenada, including Barbados. [[Storm warning]]s were issued for all islands in the Windward Islands from Saint Lucia south to [[Tobago]], excluding [[St. Vincent and the Grenadines]]. All warnings in the Windward Antilles remained in effect until 1000 UTC on September 22. Shortly after warnings were lowered in the Windward Islands, storm warnings were issued for the [[ABC islands (Lesser Antilles)|ABC islands]] and the [[Paraguaná Peninsula]] of [[Venezuela]] at 0200 UTC on September 23. After Janet passed north of the islands, all storm warnings were lifted on the morning of September 25. The Weather Bureau later warned interests in Jamaica, but did not issue any hurricane-related warnings for the island. ===Yucatán Peninsula and Mexico=== The Weather Bureau first began cautioning areas of [[Central America]] at 1600 UTC on September 26, advising people in areas of northeast [[Nicaragua]] and [[Honduras]] to take precautionary measures, along with all vessels and small craft in the [[Gulf of Honduras]] south to [[Cabo Gracias a Dios]]. After Janet began accelerating towards the west-northwest, advisories warned areas in [[British Honduras]] and [[Quintana Roo]] of hurricane-related impacts. Though no official warnings were issued for areas of Central America, advisories published by the Weather Bureau cautioned interests in the hurricane's path up until landfall. Evacuations took place in several coastal towns in Quintana Roo upon notification of the oncoming storm. People were evacuated to inland hillside shelters. After the hurricane moved through the Yucatán Peninsula and entered the Bay of Campeche, the Weather Bureau alerted areas in the storm's path on the western side of Mexico's Gulf Coast. At the time, Janet was expected to make landfall between Veracruz and [[Tuxpan, Veracruz|Tuxpan]]. Areas were warned of the storm's potential flooding and coastal impacts. The Weather Bureau advised all small craft south of [[Port O'Connor, Texas]] to remain in port. Notifications of Janet to potentially affected areas were stopped after the hurricane made landfall. ==Impact== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="float:right; margin:0 0 0.5em 1em; float:right;" |+'''Deaths and damage by region |- style="text-align:center;" ! '''Region''' !! Total
deaths !! Damage
(USD) !!! class="unsortable"|Source(s) |- | [[Barbados]] || 38 || {{ntsp|5000000||$}} || |- | [[British Honduras]] || 16 || {{ntsp|5000000||$}} || |- | [[Grenadines]] || 122 || {{ntsp|3800000||$}} || |- | [[Hurricane Hunters]] || 11 || Unknown || |- | [[Quintana Roo]] || 500 || {{ntsp|40000000||$}} || |- | [[Sonora]] || 0 || {{ntsp|12000000||$}} || |- | [[Tamaulipas]] || 326 || Unknown || |- | [[Tobago]] || 10 || Unknown || |- | [[Veracruz]] |[[ Puerto Rico ]] || Unknown || Unknown || |- class="sortbottom" ! Totals: || {{nts|1023}}+ || {{ntsp|65800000||$}} || |- class="sortbottom" | colspan = 4 | Because of differing sources, totals may not match. |} During its existence, areas of the [[Lesser Antilles]], ABC islands, and Central America were affected by Janet. At least $65.8 million in damages and 1,023 deaths were caused by the hurricane, mostly in Quintana Roo. The large number of deaths and damage caused by Janet helped make the 1955 Atlantic hurricane season the deadliest and costliest hurricane season documented since comprehensive record of such statistics began in 1942. ===Lesser Antilles=== As a small but rapidly intensifying hurricane, Janet passed just south of Barbados on September 22, becoming the first hurricane to strike the island in 57 years, since the [[1898 Windward Islands Hurricane]]. Maximum sustained winds on the south side of the island were estimated to be between 110–120 mph (180–190 km/h). The strong winds knocked out communication lines, preventing officials from accurately enumerating casualties on the island, though communications were still maintained by commercial cable companies and [[amateur radio]].{{cite news|title=Damage High on Island as Hurricane Janet Hits|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=DuZXAAAAIBAJ&sjid=sfYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2476,621598&dq=janet&hl=en|accessdate=January 24, 2013|newspaper=Spokane Daily Chronicle|date=September 23, 1955|volume=70|issue=1|agency=Associated Press|location=Spokane, Washington|page=2}} Electric power was later restored, allowing newspapers to publish information on the storm. [[Sugar cane]], the island country's main source of revenue, was severely damaged, with losses estimated to be in excess of $1 million.{{cite news|title=Janet's Winds Smash Island|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=7lUaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=qiYEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7336,4062631&dq=janet&hl=en|accessdate=January 24, 2013|newspaper=The Milwaukee Journal|date=September 22, 1955|volume=73|agency=Associated Press|location=Milwaukee, Wisconsin|page=2}} Poorly constructed dwellings were blown apart by the strong winds. An estimated 8,100 homes were damaged by the hurricane.{{cite web|title=Hurricanes & Tropical Storms|url=http://www.weready.org/CDM/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=7&Itemid=18|publisher=The Caribbean Disaster Emergency Management Agency|accessdate=January 25, 2013|year=2010}} The destroyed buildings and trees blocked [[highway]]s,{{cite news|title=Hurricane Janet Whirling Westward|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=wg5WAAAAIBAJ&sjid=auIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6785,4081384&dq=janet&hl=en|accessdate=January 24, 2013|newspaper=Eugene Register-Guard|date=September 23, 1955|volume=89|issue=265|agency=Associated Press|location=Eugene, Oregon|page=2}} and the [[Grantley Adams International Airport|Seawell Airport]] was forced to close.{{cite news|title='Janet' Hits Barbados, Thousands Homeless|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=glQxAAAAIBAJ&sjid=6g8EAAAAIBAJ&pg=1548,2033949&dq=janet&hl=en|accessdate=January 24, 2013|newspaper=The Milwaukee Sentinel|date=September 22, 1955|agency=Associated Press|location= Milwaukee, Wisconsin|page=1}} Heavy rains peaked at 4 in (100 mm) and a [[storm surge]] of 7 ft (2.1 m) swept away low-lying houses along the coast.{{cite book|last=Longshore|first=David|title=Encyclopedia of hurricanes, typhoons, and cyclones|year=2008|publisher=Facts on File|location=New York|isbn=978-0-8160-6295-9|edition=New|page=269}} An estimated 2,000 people were left homeless due to the hurricane. Property damage on Barbados was estimated to be $5 million,{{cite news|title=Hurricane Force Wanes, 2000 on Isle Homeless|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=D-ZXAAAAIBAJ&sjid=sfYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2467,770720&dq=christ+church+on+barbados&hl=en|accessdate=January 24, 2013|newspaper=Spokane Daily Chronicle|date=September 24, 1955|volume=70|issue=2|agency=Associated Press|location=Spokane, Washington|page=1}} and at least 57 people were killed.{{cite web|title=Search Details Disaster List|url=http://www.emdat.be/search-details-disaster-list|publisher=Emergency Events Database|accessdate=January 24, 2013|author=SuperAdminEMDAT}} On September 23 Janet passed directly between Grenada and Carriacou in the [[Grenadines]], killing 122 people in the [[archipelago|island chain]]. An [[airport]] on Grenada was covered in debris strewn by the strong winds. Eight people were killed in a small town adjacent to the airport. Strong winds were also reported to have destroyed docks and warehouses, and unroofed a hotel in [[St. George's, Grenada]].{{cite news|title=Janet Sweeps Path of Death|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=4KFhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=HGwDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2910,47212&dq=janet&hl=en|accessdate=January 24, 2013|newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette|date=September 23, 1955|agency=Associated Press|location=Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania|page=1}} Houses were also unroofed, and [[balcony|balconies]] of government offices in St. George's were torn off.{{cite news|title=Palm-dotted isle in ruins|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=NRtUAAAAIBAJ&sjid=6TkNAAAAIBAJ&pg=7167,3781732&dq=grenada&hl=en|accessdate=January 25, 2013|newspaper=The Leader-Post|date=September 26, 1955|agency=Reuters|location=St. George's, Grenada|page=12}} All bridges in the island's interior regions collapsed,{{cite news|title=Janet Leaves 108 Dead in West Indies|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=7SEhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=7GQEAAAAIBAJ&pg=1804,4159729&dq=janet&hl=en|accessdate=January 24, 2013|newspaper=Sarasota Herald-Tribune|date=September 23, 1955|agency=Associated Press|location=Miami, Florida|page=1}} and spice crops sustained heavy damage. An estimated 75% of [[nutmeg]] plantations were destroyed, along with nearly all of the island's banana and [[Cocoa bean|cocoa]] crops.{{cite news|title=Rush Supplies to Stricken BWI Islands|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=KFhjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Om8NAAAAIBAJ&pg=2754,3877174&dq=janet&hl=en|accessdate=January 25, 2013|newspaper=Saskatoon Star-Phoenix|date=September 27, 1955|agency=Reuters|location=Port of Spain, Trinidad|page=21}} Three ships were also grounded in the local harbor.{{cite news|title=Storm Havoc in Barbados|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ij9AAAAAIBAJ&sjid=dlkMAAAAIBAJ&pg=5199,2824578&dq=grenada&hl=en|accessdate=January 24, 2013|newspaper=The Glasgow Herald|date=September 24, 1955|agency=The Glasgow Herald|location=Glasgow, Scotland|page=5}} In The Carenage, the waterfront region of St. George's, debris was scattered and an 820 ft (250 m) [[pier]] collapsed.{{cite book|last=Cindy|first=Kligmore|title=Grenada, St Vincent & the Grenadines Adventure Guide|year=2008|publisher=Hunter Travel Guides|url=http://www.amazon.com/Grenada-Vincent-Grenadines-Adventure-ebook/dp/B001PBF0CG|edition=2nd|author2=Moore, Alan|chapter=Hurricane Janet}} [[Saint Vincent (island)|St. Vincent]] was mostly destroyed,{{cite web|title=Saint Vincent's history with tropical systems|url=http://www.hurricanecity.com/city/saintvincent.htm|publisher=Hurricanecity.com|accessdate=December 8, 2010}} and St. Lucia suffered significant coastal damage.{{cite web|title=NEMO remembers Hurricane Janet|url=http://www.cdera.org/cunews/news/saint_lucia/article_1289.php|publisher=Saint Lucia National Emergency Management Organisation|accessdate=December 8, 2010|author=NEMO Secretariat|date=September 20, 2005}} Over $2.8 million in damages were estimated throughout the Grenadines. Farther south, in [[Port of Spain]], a church being used as a storm shelter collapsed, killing ten people.{{cite news|title=Thousands Homeless as Hurricane Janet Smashes Barbados|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=JVhjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Om8NAAAAIBAJ&pg=7192,3181504&dq=janet&hl=en|accessdate=January 24, 2013|newspaper=Sakatoon Star-Phoenix|date=September 23, 1955|agency=Associated Press|location=Saskatoon, Saskatchewan|page=6}} Hurricane Janet skirted the [[ABC islands (Lesser Antilles)|ABC islands]] with strong winds as it passed to the north from September 24–25.{{Atlantic hurricane best track}} In [[Aruba]], gusts peaked at 50 mph (80 km/h), uprooting trees. However, damage outside of trees was primarily insignificant. In [[Bonaire]], piers were destroyed, and the island's coastal boulevard was damaged. Beach facilities at [[Curaçao]]'s Piscadera and Vaersen Bays suffered considerable damage. Quays along the harbor entrance were also damaged.{{cite report|url=http://www.meteo.an/Include/Climate2/documents/HurricanesandTropicalStorms.pdf|title=Hurricanes and Tropical Storms in the Netherlands Antilles and Aruba|publisher=Meteorological Service of the Netherlands Antilles and Aruba|date=April 2010|page=28–29|chapter=Hurricane Climatology of the Netherlands Antilles and Aruba|accessdate=May 12, 2013}} ====Snowcloud Five==== On September 26, the [[Hurricane Hunter]] [[Lockheed P-2 Neptune#Variants|P2V-3W Neptune]] aircraft Snowcloud Five, led by U.S. Navy [[Lieutenant Commander]] Grover B. Windham, was sent from [[Guantánamo Bay]] to investigate Janet, which was at the time a Category 4 hurricane south of [[Jamaica]].{{cite web|title=The Lost Hurricane Hunters 4: September 26th, 1955|url=http://www.wunderground.com/hurricane/hunter4.asp|publisher=Wunderground|accessdate=January 21, 2013}} Upon penetration of the hurricane's eyewall at an altitude of 700 ft (200 m), a final transmission was received from the reconnaissance flight before it presumably crashed in the Caribbean Sea. All 11 people on board, including nine crew members and two journalists, were killed.{{cite web|last=Bill|first=Murray|title=1955: Hurricane Janet and the Hurricane Hunters|url=http://www.alabamawx.com/?p=23208|publisher=The Alabama Weather Blog|accessdate=January 24, 2013}} Following the loss of the plane, an extensive [[search and rescue]] operation took place over a large area of the Caribbean Sea, with 3,000 personnel involved with the search, returning no results. The exact cause of the crash remains unknown, though it is speculated that the plane's [[altimeter]] gave an incorrect reading due to the low surrounding barometric pressure. Although four hurricane reconnaissance flights have been lost since operations began in 1943, Snowcloud Five remains the only known loss of a reconnaissance aircraft as a result of a hurricane in the Atlantic basin, with the other three occurring as a result of [[typhoon|Pacific typhoons]].{{cite web|title=Answers archive: Hurricane history and climatology|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/weather/resources/askjack/waskhurh.htm|publisher=USA Today|accessdate=January 24, 2013|author=Swanson, Bob|date=October 23, 2005}} === Yucatán Peninsula === [[File:Corozal Town Damage Hurricane Janet.jpg|thumb|right|Damage in Corozal Town|alt=Aerial black and white image of a destroyed city along the coast. Almost all buildings are flattened.]] As it approached the Yucatán Peninsula, Janet passed over the Swan Islands north of Honduras as a Category 5 hurricane on September 27.{{Atlantic hurricane best track}} The hurricane caused rough seas, and strong winds uprooted trees and [[antenna (radio)|antennas]]. After gusts exceeded an estimated 100 mph (160 km/h), officials on the islands took shelter in a Navy [[Seismometer|seismograph building]].{{cite news|title=Hurricane Janet Blasts Swan Island, Points Toward Yucatan|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=GqVHAAAAIBAJ&sjid=sv4MAAAAIBAJ&pg=597,3110588&dq=janet&hl=en|accessdate=January 25, 2013|newspaper=Meriden Record|date=September 27, 1955|agency=Associated Press|location=Miami, Florida|page=17}} Though no deaths were reported, Janet destroyed almost all buildings on the islands. The U.S. Weather Bureau and [[Civil Aeronautics Board#Civil Aeronautics Authority|Civil Aeronautics Authority]] requested food and supplies for 82 people on the island after the storm passed.{{cite news|title=Janet's Winds Lash Coast of Mexico|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=IPZOAAAAIBAJ&sjid=jwAEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6092,2772128&dq=swan+islands&hl=en|accessdate=January 25, 2013|newspaper=Toledo Blade|date=September 29, 1955|agency=Associated Press|location=Mexico City, Mexico|page=1}} ====Quintana Roo==== After passing the Swan Islands, Janet made landfall on the Yucatán Peninsula between Corozal Town, British Honduras, and Chetumal, Mexico, at 1700 UTC on September 28. At the time, it had winds of 175 mph (280 km/h).{{Atlantic hurricane best track}} [[Hurricane force]] winds were reported for two hours preceding the hurricane's landfall, with numerous pressure readings below 948 mbar (hPa; 28.00 inHg). Roads and crops on the peninsula sustained heavy damage due to Janet.{{cite news|title=Hurricane Janet Rips Into Yucatan|url=http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10715FB3A5E107B93CBAB1782D85F418585F9|accessdate=January 25, 2013|newspaper=New York Times|date=September 28, 1955|author=Kennedy, Paul P.|agency=New York Times|page=30}} In [[Xcalak, Quintana Roo]], the strong winds from Janet flattened the port's infrastructure, and only one house remained intact after the storm's passage.{{cite news|title=Hurricane Janet Flattens Seaport; Uncounted Dead|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=V3VFAAAAIBAJ&sjid=m7wMAAAAIBAJ&pg=3136,3020495&dq=janet&hl=en|accessdate=January 25, 2013|newspaper=The Telegraph-Herald|date=September 27, 1955|agency=Associated Press|location=Mexico City, Mexico|page=1}} 97 people were killed in Xcalak, constituting more than a third of the port's population.{{cite news|title=Janet Dying But Toll in Life Heavy|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=EkIaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hyMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3979,4982710&dq=janet&hl=en|accessdate=January 30, 2013|newspaper=The Times-News|date=October 1, 1955|agency=Associated Press|location=Mexico City, Mexico|page=1}} Chetumal, Mexico was devastated, with only four buildings left standing. Storm surge pushed water to a depth of 6.5 feet (2 m), 1600 ft (490 m) inland, despite the peninsula protecting the city from the open ocean. The death toll in Chetumal remains uncertain; 120 bodies were recovered in the city but it is unknown how many were ever found. An additional 10,000 people in the city were left homeless after the hurricane, and were forced to sleep in the open overnight. Federal [[relief agency|relief agencies]] previously providing service for areas affected by Hurricanes Gladys and Hilda earlier in the year in western areas of the [[Gulf Coast of Mexico]] were ordered to extend relief operations to the Yucatán Peninsula.{{cite news|title=Janet May Grow Larger; Death Toll 200 on Yucatan|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=lmJSAAAAIBAJ&sjid=eHoDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7293,5218234&dq=janet&hl=en|accessdate=January 25, 2013|newspaper=St. Petersburg Times|date=September 29, 1955|agency=Associated Press|location=Mexico City, Mexico|page=14}} In Quintana Roo, Hurricane Janet was estimated to have caused $40 million in damages and at least 500 deaths, the most of any region affected by Janet. ====British Honduras==== Making landfall near the border between Mexico and British Honduras, the latter colony's [[Corozal District|Corozal]] and [[Orange Walk District|Orange Walk]] [[Districts of Belize|districts]], containing a population of 15,500 at the time, experienced severe devastation from Janet. Strong hurricane winds knocked down and damaged numerous trees across British Honduras, particularly in the Freshwater Creek Forest Preserve. There, an estimated 30% of all trees had been damaged, especially [[mahogany]] and [[Manilkara zapota|sapodilla]] trees. Hurricane Janet also caused extensive damage to crops, with an estimated $2.631 million in damages. [[Fruit tree]]s, [[maize]], and sugar cane crops suffered the most damage. Sugar cane was expected to have a 20% decrease in yield due to the damage sustained after the storm. [[Pineapple]] crops and [[livestock]] experienced less significant losses. To a lesser extent, the hurricane also affected the [[Belize District]] and several of British Honduras' offshore [[cay]]es. Similar to Corozal and Orange Walk Districts, corn, trees, and coconut experienced the most severe damage of any crop.{{cite web|title=Hurricane Janet : Progress report no. 1 (27th/28th September, 1955)|url=http://ufdc.ufl.edu/UF00095346/00001/pdf|publisher=University of Florida Digital Collections|accessdate=January 26, 2013|date=November 11, 1955}} In [[Corozal Town|Corozal Town, British Honduras]], south of where Janet made landfall, 500 people were made homeless, and six people were killed. About 90% of all buildings in the town were destroyed,{{cite news|title=5 Dead, Town Razed|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=EuZXAAAAIBAJ&sjid=sfYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3794,1980555&dq=janet&hl=en|accessdate=January 25, 2013|newspaper=Spokane Daily Chronicle|date=September 28, 1955|agency=Associated Press|location=Albuquerque, New Mexico|page=1}} and communications were knocked out by the strong winds.{{cite news|title='Killer' Janet Slaps Yucatan|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=QKQRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=vOYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=899,2169779&dq=janet&hl=en|accessdate=January 25, 2013|newspaper=The Spokesman-Review|date=September 28, 1955|agency=Associated Press|page=15}} Based on an average home cost of $2,000, it was estimated that property damage to homes in Corozal Town totaled $800,000. Much of [[Santa Elena, British Honduras]] was also flattened by the strong winds.{{cite news|title=Hurricane Bears Down on Mexico|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=aJpWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=qEENAAAAIBAJ&pg=886,3292048&dq=chetumal&hl=en|accessdate=January 25, 2013|newspaper=Greensburg Daily Tribune|date=September 29, 1955|agency=United Press International|location=Mexico City, Mexico|page=16}} Farther south in [[Belize City]], winds peaked at 60 mph (100 km/h), though no damage was reported.{{cite news|title=Janet Roaring Across Yucatan|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=en9PAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ugQEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5976,2363188&dq=janet&hl=en|accessdate=January 25, 2013|newspaper=Ocala Star-Banner|date=September 28, 1955|agency=Associated Press|location=Miami, Florida|page=9}} In British Honduras, the hurricane's effects were less deadly than in Quintana Roo,{{cite news|title=Hurricane Janet Hits Coast Near Vera Cruz; Storm's Toll About 400|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=aXgKAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hUsDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5875,4809850&dq=corozal&hl=en|accessdate=January 25, 2013|newspaper=Ellensburg Daily Record|date=September 29, 2013|agency=Associated Press|location=Mexico City, Mexico|page=1}} but in northern portions of the colony the storm killed 16 people and caused $5 million in damages. ===Mainland Mexico=== [[File:Tampico Flood Damage Hurricane Janet.jpg|thumb|Helicopter observing flood damage in Tampico|alt=Sepia-toned helicopter view of a city with roads flooded by water and buildings damaged. Another helicopter can be seen near the middle of the image.]] While in the Bay of Campeche, the [[fishing vessel|shrimp boat]] ''Celestino Arias'' was sunken by strong waves generated by Janet after it suffered [[engine failure]]s. The stranded ship was heavily damaged by the hurricane's strong winds in the bay, which broke towing lines. All of the ship's crewmen, which had evacuated the boat after it sunk, were later rescued and brought back to [[Tampa, Florida]].{{cite news|title=Janet Sinks Tampa Boat; Sailor Saved|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=l2JSAAAAIBAJ&sjid=eHoDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3543,5437070&dq=janet&hl=en|accessdate=January 30, 2013|newspaper=St. Petersburg Times|date=September 30, 1955|location=Tampa. Florida|page=1}} Along the coast, tides were reported to be 3–4 ft (0.91–1.2 m) above average. Farther north along the Texas coast, tides were 2 ft (0.61 m) above average, blocking beach roads near [[Corpus Christi, Texas|Corpus Christi]].{{cite book|pages=326–328|title=Tropical Storms of the North Atlantic, September 1955|author=Rhodes, C.E.|publisher=United States Weather Bureau|url=https://books.google.com/?id=pRrOAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA326&dq=hurricane+hilda+1955#v=onepage&q=hurricane%20hilda%201955&f=false|year=1955}} Janet made its final landfall in the Mexican state of [[Veracruz]] between the cities of [[Nautla]] and [[Veracruz, Veracruz|Veracruz]] as a Category 2 hurricane at 2200 UTC on September 29.{{Atlantic hurricane best track}} In Nautla, communications were cut by strong winds from the hurricane.{{cite news|title=Mexico Flooded as Mountains Repulse Janet|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=PN5LAAAAIBAJ&sjid=3ooDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3628,88377&dq=janet&hl=en|accessdate=January 30, 2013|newspaper=The Free Lance-Star|date=September 30, 1955|agency=Associated Press|location=Mexico City|page=1}} The strong winds also caused a relief plane to crash, causing five deaths. Heavy rains in the [[Tampico, Tamaulipas|Tampico]], [[Tamaulipas]] area added to floods caused by hurricanes Gladys and Hilda earlier in the year. The resulting flood was reported by the Weather Bureau office in New Orleans to be one of the worst [[natural disaster]]s in Mexican history. In Tampico, 16 in (410 mm) of rain was reported.{{cite news|title=Deluge Floods Coastal Areas|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Q6QRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=vOYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=974,3129815&dq=janet&hl=en|accessdate=January 30, 2013|newspaper=The Spokesman-Review|date=September 30, 1955|agency=Associated Press|location=Mexico City, Mexico|page=12}} The floods contributed to a localized [[typhoid fever]] and [[dysentery]] outbreak,{{cite news|title='Janet' Blowing Out; 400 Dead|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=iVQxAAAAIBAJ&sjid=6g8EAAAAIBAJ&pg=7431,3994798&dq=janet&hl=en|accessdate=January 30, 2013|newspaper=The Milwaukee Sentinel|date=September 29, 1955|agency=Associated Pres|location=Mexico City, Mexico|page=7}}{{cite news|title=Mexico Coast Faces New Flood Threat|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=QMVQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=rdAMAAAAIBAJ&pg=1480,6012561&dq=janet&hl=en|accessdate=January 30, 2013|newspaper=The Portsmouth Times|date=September 30, 1955|agency=Associated Press|location=Mexico City, Mexico|page=1,4}} causing over 1,000 people to evacuate out of the city to prevent further spreading of the diseases. An additional 36,000 people were being cared for in concentration centers. Although located south of where Janet made landfall, areas of Veracruz were inundated by strong [[storm surge]], including the city's main streets and port. Operations along a [[railroad]] stretching from [[Laredo, Texas]] to [[Mexico City]] were stopped, after having just reopened due to Hurricane Hilda.{{cite news|title=Floods Delay Reports of Janet's Mexico Toll|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=hngcAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5GQEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4051,70280&dq=janet&hl=en|accessdate=January 30, 2013|newspaper=Sarasota Herald-Tribune|date=September 30, 1955|agency=Associated Press|location=Mexico City, Mexico|page=8}} Farther inland, as Janet dissipated over the mountainous central Mexico, the storm dropped torrential rainfall over the Tamisi and [[Panuco River]] basins. The water levels in the Panuco River remained above [[flood stage]] for four weeks.{{cite news|title=Hurricane in Mexico Takes Terrible Toll|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=2IcbAAAAIBAJ&sjid=zFAEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3534,5071945&dq=janet&hl=en|accessdate=January 30, 2013|newspaper=The Dispatch|date=October 1, 1955|agency=Associated Press|location=Mexico City, Mexico|page=1}} In Tampico, the river flooded neighborhoods, forcing cables to be stretched along roads to prevent people from being swept away. Small boats were also sent to monitor streets.{{cite news|title=Record Floods Sweep Tampico|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=JfZOAAAAIBAJ&sjid=jwAEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6726,4868694&dq=janet&hl=en|accessdate=January 30, 2013|newspaper=Toledo Blade'|date=October 4, 1955|agency=Associated Press|location=Mexico City, Mexico|page=2}} According to some sources, 800 people died from the floods, with thousands more being stranded in the city.{{cite web|title=Preventative Medicine in Military Operations Other Than War|url=https://ke.army.mil/bordeninstitute/published_volumes/mpmVol1/PM1ch4.pdf|format=PDF|work=Historic Perspective on the Principles of Military Preventive Medicine|publisher=U.S. Army Medical Department|accessdate=January 31, 2013|author=Erickson, Ralph Loren|page=89}} [[Tamazunchale]] was inundated by an overflowing [[Moctezuma River]].{{cite news|title=Mexican Floods Still Grow|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=2zJAAAAAIBAJ&sjid=G1kMAAAAIBAJ&pg=7350,29557&dq=janet&hl=en|accessdate=January 30, 2013|newspaper=The Robesonian|date=October 3, 1955|agency=Associated Press|location=Mexico City|page=5}} The rains caused a [[landslide]] in [[Colonia San Rafael]], killing 12 people.{{cite news|title=Janet Kills 17 More Before Blowing Out|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=YMtaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=dHoDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7128,309494&dq=janet&hl=en|accessdate=January 30, 2013|newspaper=St. Petersburg Times|date=October 2, 1955|agency=Associated Press|location=Mexico City, Mexico|page=7A}} Heavy rains also impacted [[Guadalajara]], which had previously not been affected by any tropical cyclones earlier in the year. In Maltarana, [[Jalisco]], the [[Lerma River|Lerma]] and [[Duero River (Mexico)|Duero River]]s overflowed, forcing 800 people in the town to evacuate. Farther north, in [[Sonora]], cotton crops damaged by Janet were estimated to amount to $12 million in damages. Combined property damage in Mexico from Hurricanes Gladys, Hilda, and Janet was estimated to total $200 million, nearly half of the government's 1955 [[government budget|national budget]].{{cite news|title=New Floods in Mexico|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=WWlYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=rzkNAAAAIBAJ&pg=3376,86308&dq=janet&hl=en|accessdate=January 30, 2013|newspaper=St. Joseph News-Press|date=September 30, 1955|agency=Associated Press|location=Mexico City, Mexico|page=15}} Although there were no official damage or fatality estimates, at least 1,000 people were injured and another 100,000 people were made homeless on the Mexican mainland due to Janet.{{cite news|title=Record-Breaking Mexican Floods Are Rising Fast|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=qPNXAAAAIBAJ&sjid=qvYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3317,397299&dq=janet&hl=en|accessdate=January 30, 2013|newspaper=Spokane Daily Chronicle|date=October 3, 1955|agency=Associated Press|location=Tampico, Mexico|page=1}} ==Aftermath== {{See also|List of retired Atlantic hurricane names}} [[File:NHA Rebuilding Barbados Neighborhood 1955.png|thumb|Neighborhood being rebuilt in Barbados|alt=Slightly elevated view of workers constructing an entire neighborhood. The houses are all of similar appearance, with windows and a door.]] ===Lesser Antilles=== After Janet passed Barbados, the island was declared a [[state of emergency]].{{cite news|title=Over 100 Perish When Hurricane Janet Lashes Barbados; Losses Heavy|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ZHgKAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hUsDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5618,4493753&dq=janet&hl=en|accessdate=January 24, 2013|newspaper=Ellensburg Daily Record|date=September 23, 1955|volume=46|issue=72|agency=Associated Press|location=Ellensburg, Washington|page=1}} Relief workers on Barbados helped to clean up debris scattered by the strong winds on highways, and the local government made requests for food and construction materials.{{cite news|title=Janet Poses Threat for Venezuela|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=DEIaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hyMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3139,4608635&dq=janet&hl=en|accessdate=January 24, 2013|newspaper=The Times-News|date=September 24, 1955|agency=Associated Press|location=Miami, Florida|page=1}} The extensive damaged caused by Janet on the island to low-income households led the passage of the 1955 Housing Act, which created the National Housing Authority (NHA) in 1956. The NHA was responsible for the acquisition of lands on which houses could be built with stronger and more permanent materials, which was thought to minimize maintenance costs and hurricane-related damage. The newly founded organization quickly worked to rebuild homes after the hurricane struck.{{cite book|last=Watson|first=Mark R.|title=Low-cost housing in Barbados : evolution or social revolution?|year=2001|publisher=University of the West Indies Press|location=Kingston|isbn=978-976-640-048-4|page=90|url=https://books.google.com/?id=k2kiaI1lDu8C&pg=PA90&lpg=PA90&dq=christ+church+barbados+hurricane+janet#v=onepage&q=christ%20church%20barbados%20hurricane%20janet&f=false|edition=1.|author2=Potter, Robert B.|chapter=The Work of the Barbadian Housing Authority: 1955–1973}} In Grenada, the island's governor issued an emergency order against the [[hoarding]] of food in the aftermath of Janet, due to the food and water shortage that resulted from Janet. A United States [[destroyer (ship)|destroyer]] and a British [[frigate]] were sent to bring relief supplies to Grenada, and ships departing from Jamaica and Trinidad were redirected to the island to help send supplies.{{cite news|title=Hurricane Aid Rushed to Grenada|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=NhtUAAAAIBAJ&sjid=6TkNAAAAIBAJ&pg=3136,3878068&dq=janet&hl=en|accessdate=January 25, 2013|newspaper=The Leader-Post|date=September 27, 1955|agency=Reuters|location=Port of Spain, Trinidad|page=1}} The British government later announced that it would send [[British Pound|£]]50,000 (US$155,000) in relief to the Grenadines.{{#tag:ref|Conversions from British Pounds to United States Dollars were done using a currency converter with an exchange date of September 29, 1955.{{cite web|title=Converter in the past|url=http://fxtop.com/en/currency-converter-past.php?A=55000&C1=GBP&C2=USD&DD=29&MM=09&YYYY=1955&B=1&P=&I=1&btnOK=Go!|publisher=Fxtop.com|accessdate=February 2, 2013}}|group="nb"}}{{cite news|title=Hurricane Kills 350 and Roars on Into Mexico|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=LihBAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hqgMAAAAIBAJ&pg=7003,2986416&dq=british+honduras&hl=en|accessdate=January 25, 2013|newspaper=Evening Times|date=September 29, 1955|page=5}} The [[Crown Agents for Oversea Governments and Administrations Ltd|Crown Agents]] and [[International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement|Red Cross]] delivered relief supplies to Barbados and the Grenadines, which included aluminum roofing sheets and portable [[electric generator]]s.{{cite news|title=More Deaths in Storm|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=jz9AAAAAIBAJ&sjid=dlkMAAAAIBAJ&pg=3673,3452633&dq=barbados&hl=en|accessdate=January 31, 2013|newspaper=The Glasgow Herald|date=September 30, 1955|page=7}} ===British Honduras and Mexico=== Relief and reconstruction measures were enacted in the British Honduras beginning on September 30. A large-scale reconstruction program was initiated by the government to help rebuild 48 villages.{{cite news|title=To Rebuild Villages|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=l4EtAAAAIBAJ&sjid=TpkFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5429,3255581&dq=hurricane+diane&hl=en|accessdate=February 13, 2013|newspaper=The Montreal Gazette|date=October 18, 1955|location=Corozal, British Honduras|page=2}} The government also declared a state of emergency for Corozal, Orange Walk, and Belize administrative districts, including a ban on [[liquor]] sales. Temporary communication lines were rebuilt, which initially only allowed official communications with affected areas. Due to the severity of the damage in Corozal, an [[airstrip]] was built to help deliver relief to the city more efficiently. Food depots in Corozal, [[Louisville, Belize|Louisville]], and [[Orange Walk Town]] were tasked with distributing food. The potential for widespread disease following the devastation wrought by Janet forced a widespread [[vaccine|vaccination]] initiative against typhoid fever in affected areas. The Jamaican government sent £20,000 (US$55,000) to the colony in relief funds, while the British government sent £40,000 (US$110,000) to affected areas in the British Honduras and other affected islands in the Caribbean. The United States sent the [[cargo ship]] ''[[USS Antares (AK-258)|USS Antares]]'', which supplied the colony with various relief materials. In Corozal Town, a $3.5 million grant was given to [[Surveying#Land surveyor|land surveyor]] H.C. Fairweather to plan and reconstruct the township.{{cite web|title=Hurricane Janet|url=http://www.corozal.com/history/janet|publisher=Corozal|accessdate=March 3, 2013|location=Corozal, Belize}} A U.S. Navy relief plane was sent to Chetumal, Mexico, to deliver food and other relief supplies after Janet struck the region.{{cite news|title=Janet Has Been Here|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=qvAdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=pVoEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6948,3680056&dq=chetumal&hl=en|accessdate=February 1, 2013|newspaper=The Victoria Advocate|date=October 5, 1955|page=1}} In areas previously affected by hurricanes Gladys and Hilda earlier in the year, federal [[relief agency|relief agencies]] were ordered to extend relief operations to the Yucatán Peninsula. However, after crossing the Bay of Campeche and making landfall near Veracruz, relief measures were once again implemented in the western Gulf Coast of Mexico. The [[Mexican Air Force]], commercial and private planes, and [[helicopters]] were sent to bring relief supplies and [[airlift]] refugees.{{cite news|title=Aid Rushed To Victims of Janet's Fury|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=WXVFAAAAIBAJ&sjid=m7wMAAAAIBAJ&pg=3192,3386190&dq=relief+hurricane&hl=en|accessdate=February 1, 2013|newspaper=The Telegraph-Herald|date=September 30, 1955|agency=Associated Press|location=Mexico City, Mexico|page=6}} The United States initiated the largest relief campaign ever staged in Mexico at the time. Various government and relief agencies, including the [[American Red Cross]] and [[The Salvation Army]], participated in the relief efforts.{{cite news|title=Tampico Toll 326|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=sB9UAAAAIBAJ&sjid=DjoNAAAAIBAJ&pg=1531,763070&dq=relief+hurricane&hl=en|accessdate=February 1, 2013|newspaper=The Leader-Post|date=October 6, 1955|agency=Associated Press|location=Mexico City, Mexico|page=1}} The [[United States Air Force]] and [[United States Army]] began a joint-relief operation to send relief supplies to the Tampico area, beginning with the deployment of a [[Curtiss C-46 Commando]] from the [[Harlingen Air Force Base]] on October 1. Ten other [[military transport aircraft]] from the [[United States Air Force]] were sent from Texas to provide food and clothing. [[Pan American World Airways]] sent a [[Boeing 314]] from [[Miami, Florida]] to evacuate victims.{{cite news|title=US Aid To Mexico As Rains Continue Floods|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=3jJAAAAAIBAJ&sjid=G1kMAAAAIBAJ&pg=7165,353990&dq=relief+hurricane&hl=en|accessdate=February 1, 2013|newspaper=The Robesonian|date=October 6, 1955|author=Rutledge, Jack|agency=Associated Press|location=Mexico City, Mexico|page=23}} Helicopters were sent from the [[USS Saipan (CVL-48)|USS Saipan]] to transfer food and medical supplies from the [[light aircraft carrier]]. Other ships also aided in delivering supplies,{{cite news|title=Eastern Mexico Battles Floods|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=fn9PAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ugQEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5099,3144011&dq=relief+hurricane&hl=en|accessdate=February 1, 2013|newspaper=Ocala Star-Banner|date=October 3, 1955|agency=Associated Press|location=Mexico City, Mexico|page=7}} including the [[USS Siboney (CVE-112)|USS Siboney]], which also deployed helicopters to assist in relief efforts. By October 6, 1,500 people were estimated to have been rescued from the Tampico area, and at least 280,000 lb (130,000 kg) of food and clothing materials were estimated to have been delivered by the US Air Force to the city. There, typhoid [[serum (blood)|serum]] shots were administered as a precautionary measure.{{cite news|title=Rising Waters Push Tampico Toll to 326|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ObRFAAAAIBAJ&sjid=YM8MAAAAIBAJ&pg=4824,493431&dq=relief+hurricane&hl=en|accessdate=February 1, 2013|newspaper=The Portsmouth Times|date=October 6, 1955|volume=104|issue=170|agency=Associated Press|location=Portsmouth, Ohio|page=1,11}} Former [[president of Mexico|president]] [[Manuel Ávila Camacho]] died of a heart ailment, in part due to over-exertion in helping in the relief efforts.{{cite news|title=Camancho, Ex-President O Mexico, Dies|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=KKVHAAAAIBAJ&sjid=sv4MAAAAIBAJ&pg=4264,5123537&dq=relief+hurricane&hl=en|accessdate=February 1, 2013|newspaper=Meriden Record|date=October 13, 1955|agency=Associated Press|location=Mexico City, Mexico|page=2}} Due to its large swath of destruction, the name ''Janet'' was [[List of retired Atlantic hurricanes|retired]] by the Weather Bureau, becoming just the seventh Atlantic tropical cyclone to have its name retired, and the fourth to be retired in 1955.{{cite web|title=Tropical Cyclone Naming History and Retired Names|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/aboutnames_history.shtml|publisher=United States National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|accessdate=January 31, 2013|author=National Hurricane Center|date=April 13, 2012}} {{clear}} ==See also== {{Portal|Tropical cyclones}} * [[List of Atlantic hurricanes]] * [[List of Category 5 Atlantic hurricanes]] * [[Hurricane Carmen]] * [[Hurricane Keith]] ==Notes== {{Reflist|group=nb}} ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{Retired Atlantic hurricanes}} {{Category 5 Atlantic hurricanes}} {{1955 Atlantic hurricane season buttons}} Windward Islands|Janet]] [[Category:Hurricanes in the Windward Islands|Janet]] [[Category:Hurricanes in Barbados|Janet]] [[Category:Hurricanes in Saint Lucia|Janet]] [[Category:Hurricanes in Saint Vincent and the Grenadines|Janet]] [[Category:Hurricanes in Grenada|Janet]] [[Category:Hurricanes in Belize|Janet]] [[Category:Atlantic hurricanes in Mexico|Janet]] [[Category:Retired Atlantic hurricanes|Janet]] [[Category:Hurricanes in the ABC Islands|Janet]] [[Category:British Saint Vincent and the Grenadines]] [[Category:British Saint Lucia]] [[Category:Colony of Barbados]] [[Category:British Honduras]] [[Category:British Grenada]]
